title-group.article-title: Korovkin Tests, Approximation, and Ergodic Theory

abstract.p: We consider sequences of s · k(n) x t · k(n) matrices {A<sub>n</sub>(f)} with a block structure spectrally distributed as an L<sub>1</sub> p-variate s x t matrix-valued function f, and, for any n, we suppose that A<sub>n</sub>(·) is a linear and positive operator. For every fixed n we approximate the matrix A<sub>n</sub>(f) in a suitable linear space M<sub>n</sub> of s · k(n) x t · k(n) matrices by minimizing the Frobenius norm of A<sub>n</sub>(f) - X<sub>n</sub> when X<sub>n</sub> ranges over M<sub>n</sub>. The minimizer X̂<sub>n</sub> is denoted by P<sub>k(n)</sub>(A<sub>n</sub>(f)). We show that only a simple Korovkin test over a finite number of polynomial test functions has to be performed in order to prove the following general facts: 1. the sequence { P<sub>k</sub>(n) (A<sub>n</sub>(f))} is distributed as f, 2. the sequence {A<sub>n</sub>(f) - P<sub>k(<sub>n</sub>)</sub> (A<sub>n</sub>(f))} is distributed as the constant function 0 (i.e. is spectrally clustered at zero). The first result is an ergodic one which can be used for solving numerical approximation theory problems. The second has a natural interpretation in the theory of the preconditioning associated to cg-like algorithms.
